description:
The annual film festival calendar has a distinct rhythm and the slide-down into award season begins with Toronto in September. And it has a particular record for launching successful British films, including Danny Boyle's Slumdog Millionaire and The King's Speech, both of which won the Toronto Audience Award before becoming internationally recognised, not least with Best Picture at the Oscars. So there's an inevitable anticipation amongst British filmmakers when the two men who run the festival are in town this week, to select the 2015 programme. They are Piers Handling, who's been chief executive since 1994, and artistic director Cameron Bailey. They came into the studio at the beginning of a typical selector's day. Piers outlined how it might unfold.

"Oh my god, you get up in the morning, you have breakfast, thank god, and then you kind of go off to screening rooms. You're actually locked in screening rooms from about 9:00, 9:30 in the morning till 6:00 at night. You always have a lunch. You go out professionally with sales agents, producers, whomever. I think today we're having lunch with the BFI people in the BFI unit you know really well. You often have a drink after your screenings, and then you're off to dinner. And dinner again is with people you've known for many many years, but who all bring you films in one way or another. You get to see everything that's new, sometimes very rough, not finished. It's a really comprehensive trip actually. We've been doing it for about 25 years now."

"It can be a bit daunting sometimes. There're 65 films on the list of UK production that we're going to be looking at while we're here and we'll take some of them back with us as well."
